Studentlife R6

Source: vignettes/tutorial/usecase_studentlife_R6.Rmd
usecase_studentlife_R6.Rmd

Here we show how to extract the same features which we extracted here by using the R6 Class Project.

Initialize Object

library(fxtract)
my_project = Project$new("my_project")

Load Data into Object

my_project$add_data(studentlife_small, group_by = "userId")

Preprocess Data

Add weekday and date information to dataset:

my_project$preprocess_data(fun = function(x) add_weekday(x, utc_col = "timestamp"))
my_project$preprocess_data(fun = function(x) add_date(x, utc_col = "timestamp"))

Define Feature Functions

number_diff_apps = function(data) {
  c(number_diff_apps = length(unique(data$RUNNING_TASKS_topActivity_mPackage)))
}

number_diff_apps_weekday = function(data) {
  data_weekday = data %>% filter(weekday >= "Mon" & weekday <= "Fri")
  c(number_diff_apps_weekday = length(unique(data_weekday$RUNNING_TASKS_topActivity_mPackage)))
}

daily_number_diff_apps = function(data) {
  x = fxtract::calc_feature(data, group_by = "date", fun = number_diff_apps)
  c(daily_number_diff_apps = mean(x$number_diff_apps))
}

total_dist = function(data) {
  library(geosphere)
  long = data$longitude
  lat = data$latitude
  c(total_dist = sum(distHaversine(cbind(long, lat)), na.rm = TRUE))
}

Add Feature Functions to R6 Object

my_project$add_feature(number_diff_apps)
my_project$add_feature(number_diff_apps_weekday)
my_project$add_feature(daily_number_diff_apps)
my_project$add_feature(total_dist)

Get an Overview

print(my_project)
## R6 Object 
## Project name: my_project
## Grouping variable: userId
## IDs: 00, 01, 02
## Feature functions: number_diff_apps, number_diff_apps_weekday, daily_number_diff_apps, total_dist
## Percentage calculated: 0%

Calculate Features

Let’s calculate the features in parallel (here on a windows machine):

my_project$reg$cluster.functions = batchtools::makeClusterFunctionsSocket(4)
my_project$calc_features()
## Submitting 12 jobs in 12 chunks using cluster functions 'Socket' ...

Bug Fixing

batchtools::getStatus(reg = my_project$reg)
## Status for 12 jobs at 2019-01-16 23:04:52:
##   Submitted    : 12 (100.0%)
##   -- Queued    :  0 (  0.0%)
##   -- Started   : 11 ( 91.7%)
##   ---- Running :  1 (  8.3%)
##   ---- Done    :  7 ( 58.3%)
##   ---- Error   :  3 ( 25.0%)
##   ---- Expired :  1 (  8.3%)

Some jobs failed. Let’s debug this now.

We can get the error messages:

my_project$error_messages
##    job.id
## 1:      4
## 2:      5
## 3:      6
##                                                                                                error
## 1: Error in data %>% filter(weekday >= "Mon" & weekday <= "Fri") : \n  could not find function "%>%"
## 2: Error in data %>% filter(weekday >= "Mon" & weekday <= "Fri") : \n  could not find function "%>%"
## 3: Error in data %>% filter(weekday >= "Mon" & weekday <= "Fri") : \n  could not find function "%>%"
##    problem                algorithm
## 1:      00 number_diff_apps_weekday
## 2:      01 number_diff_apps_weekday
## 3:      02 number_diff_apps_weekday

Because we calculated the functions in parallel, we need to make sure the workers have access to functions and packages. In most of our feature functions we used library() inside the functions or directly used the :: operator.

Our function number_diff_apps_weekday uses dplyr functions without calling library(dplyr) within the function. We could update this feature function (see here), but we’d like to show a different way.

You can set packages, which should be available by the workers by:

my_project$reg$packages = c("dplyr")

Now we calculate the remaining features:

my_project$calc_features()
## Submitting 3 jobs in 3 chunks using cluster functions 'Socket' ...
my_project$results
##   userId daily_number_diff_apps number_diff_apps number_diff_apps_weekday
## 1     00               16.86905               93                       NA
## 2     01                9.60000               43                       43
## 3     02               18.14286               72                       NA
##   total_dist
## 1  621719.25
## 2   44649.62
## 3  108303.26
